creator: dev@tomcat.apache.org
text: I wanted to bind context URL to my 'root' or 'welcome' servlet. In 'web.xml' I defined 'default servlet' as: MyTest / Servlet works, but all resources specified in generated HTML document becomes inaccessible. Examples (this is 'root' context): I suspict that for all URLs, that belong to context, all requests are redirected to 'default servlet' if it defined. But I just wanted to map this servlet to context path URL. When I change 'url-pattern' to any other, for example '/test', document (with '/test' appended to URL) are displayed correctly. In this situation I have to use 'static' index.html as 'welcome' page.

creator: craig.mcclanahan@sun.com
text:
This is not a bug, the correct config to achieve what you want is :

<servlet-mapping>
 <servlet-name>
   MyTest
 </servlet-name>
 <url-pattern>
   /*
 </url-pattern>
</servlet-mapping>

For query purposes, mark as fixed for Tomcat 3.3:
Fixed in Tomcat 3.3
creator: Larry.Isaacs@sas.com

text:
Using /* as mapping is no solution, since all static resources are mapped to 
the respective servlet. For me this usually results in a loop: The main servlet 
forwards to a jsp and this call is mapped to the servlet again.
I don't think, that this the expected behaviour of the "default servlet" like 
it is defined in the servlet specification. There must be a way to map the 
context path to a servlet. This is especially important for multichanneling 
applications where an index.html file in the main directory that forwards to a 
servlet is not sufficient.
creator: huegen@iconomed.de
Larry.Isaacs@sas.com
text:
Though I don't find it explicitly in the Servlet 2.2 or 2.3 specs, it is my
understanding that it is the "default servlet" that serves requests for static
resources such as the ".css" and ".gif" files.  If you replace the "default
servlet" with your own, your servlet must be prepared to handle that task.
